title: Angular momentum conservation - angular speed afte

content.description: A wheel is free to rotate with negligible friction about a fixed axle at its center. In separate experimental trials, different pieces of clay are launched toward the wheelâ€™s rim, and each piece of clay collides with and sticks to the outer rim of the wheel, as shown in the figure. The wheel has a mass <math alttext="m sub w, equals 0.080 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.080</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mstyle></math>, a radius <math alttext="r sub w, equals 0.40 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mstyle></math>, and rotational inertia about its center <math alttext="I sub w equals, m sub w, end sub, r sub w, end sub, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub><msup><msub><mi>r</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>. Clay pieces of different mass are used in two different experimental trials.
content.question: In the first experimental trial, the wheel is initially at rest and the clay has a mass of <math alttext="0.040 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>0.040</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mstyle></math>. Just before the clay collides with and sticks to the top of the outer rim of the wheel, the clay is moving directly to the right at a speed of <math alttext="12 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>12</mtext><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mstyle></math>.
